text: oh sorry well well well well well well
well hi everyone
Anthony Fantan oh here the Internet's
most metallic music nerd I know this
album really isn't news to anyone but I
feel like talking about it these guys
have been rocking and reeling in
Auckland New Zealand since about 2000 I
hope someone gets that joke and this is
the band's third LP and when it came out
back in January
earlier this year toward the end of that
month and I first heard it I was not
ready for it I was not ready for this
I didn't assume this album to be bad but
I was not in a mental state to kind of
take on a behemoth a mammoth like this
and get into its intricacies and really
try to understand it for what it is you
guys know from my previous reviews I
love detail in my albums I love changes
I love surprises and left hooks and when
it comes to that this album loves to
tango and not only that but it is loud
it is dizzyingly technical it is heavy
it is aggressive so kind of revisiting
this LP to take in more of its details
is kind of like returning for more
punishment it's a death metal album
maybe a technical death metal album not
really a style I cover much on this
channel but the thing is I honestly
haven't loved much death metal since the
genres heyday for me the Styles emphasis
on being extreme has led to a lot of
bitten bands and albums shooting for
studio tricks that kind of end up making
their music sound loud but a lot like
plastic and other records try to be more
brutal through technicality but end up
kind of sounding like meaningless wanker
II that does not resonate with me on any
level
even on musicianship thankfully this
album is a welcome change of pace from
both of those things
even though destroyers of all sounds
very very expensive the recording is so
organic to me the way the drums and
guitars bounce off of each other feels
so natural and just kind of keeps me
invested into every twist and turn this
album makes and while it is really
technical the virtuosity these guys
display doesn't just get wasted on
showing you how great they are
individually but as a unit crafting
these spiraling metal songs that are
just so easy to get lost in now in
comparison with ulcerates past two
releases this album is a slightly easier
pill to swallow but not by much it's
still a very overbearing set of seven
songs ulcery is turning up the
atmosphere and turning down the tempo a
little bit to the point where I could
see even doom and sludge metal fans
getting into this album I know the first
three tracks of this LP can be really
intense and if you're listening they'll
throw a lot at you but if you manage to
stick with destroyers of all into its
second half it's really surprising to
see how great these guys are writing
slower songs as well the fourth track is
a really brooding one that sounds
basically like these guys are playing in
an Avant metal jam and things get even
heavier and Atmospheric on my favorite
track of the cell pee omens where the
drumming is just great
it's just jumping from the left side to
the right side all the Tom's all of the
cymbals just sound like they're in
different places it's so panoramic it's
like hearing the drums dance around in
this fog of distorted bass and guitar
and it builds up to the more aggressive
moments in that song really seamlessly -
now the final track which is the title
track justifies its 10-minute length and
kind of crumbles the world that these
guys just spend building with the
previous 40 minutes
of music a really cinematic ending to
this album now if I were to name some
some problems I am having with this LP I
feel like maybe the vocals and and the
guitar tones too could have changed up a
little bit and would have aided with
being able to separate these songs in my
head plus some of these tracks are so
Rubik's Cube ish like being puzzling is
is one of the best traits and obviously
as I listen to this album again and
again and again that unpredictability
kind of waned for me I guess my only
other issue with destroyers of all is is
just with how prominent the drums are
and don't get me wrong
Jami the drummer from this band is is
quite possibly the backbone I mean
ulcery would not be all sorry if the
drums were not this detailed not this
technical not this flashy but I think a
little extra guitar volume would have
brought the atmospheric element of this
album kind of full circle plus I think
the the bass kind of gets shafted on
this album even though my finger isn't
always on the pulse of the style of
music I'm not stupid I know when I'm
hearing something good the the tenants
of creativity and interesting sounds
still apply no matter what the genre and
this LP definitely has a lot of that
feeling a decent too strong seven on
this album and if you are into metal
music and this somehow slipped by you I
recommend you go back and listen to it
hmm Anthony Fantana ulcerate destroyers
of all what do you think about this
album and what should I review next
forever
you
